ygData.subject: Re: Random Complexification
ygData.msgSnippet: Derek, good question and I definitely understand where you re coming from. The key point that is perhaps not clear is that the lines in the middle are *not*

Derek, good question and I definitely understand where you're
coming from.  

The key point that is perhaps not clear is that the lines
in the middle are *not* graphs of average complexity, but 
rather of *dominant's complexity*.  In other words, they
show the complexity of strictly superior strategies.  
The point is, yes of course, those runs as well may have a
broad range of complexity, but the question is, is there
reason to believe that the *new high levels of dominance*
should by necessity be more complex?

The random run lines clearly indicate the answer is no, 
because the population maintains a broad range of complexity
when there is no correlation between complexity and fitness.

You see the key underlying issue is that IF complexity did
NOT correlate to superiority in the robot duel, then it is
*possible* in NEAT for the complexity of the highest dominant
solutions NOT to go up.  And the reason it is possible is
because, as the random run lines show, NEAT keeps simple 
solutions around as long as they are competitive.  

I think maybe there is some confusion about what is being 
claimed; the claim is not that average complexity in NEAT
runs does not go up.  Rather, the claim is that increasing
sophistication is a result of increasing complexity, and
further that the reason increasing complexity pairs with
increasing sophistication is NOT because of some nuance of
NEAT; it is because it is fundamentally advantageous to have 
more structure in this domain.

So in other words, in a stagnating population, of course
average complexity goes up- but that makes sense- when you
are stagnating, you want to open up more options.  But
what about when you are NOT stagnating- that's what's 
interesting- in that case, adding structure opens the door
to more and more sophisticated behavior.

I don't think anyone who uses NEAT really finds that 
controversial; after all, that's the whole reason we
are using NEAT isn't it?  ...because we want to be able
to find more and more complex solutions, because we 
believe that will lead to more and more interesting 
behavior.  So that's all this result is meant to 
establish- that indeed, increasing complexity does
lead to increasing dominance.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> I was reading Ken's updated paper on Competitive
> Coevolution through Evolutionary Complexification, and
> I came across the Evolution of Complexity section
> (6.1):
> 
>
http://www-2.cs.cmu.edu/afs/cs/project/jair/pub/vo
lume21/stanley04a-html/node6.html#SECTION00063000000000000000
> 
> It bears on a previous discussion we've had here on
> the list, and I'd like to point out a couple of
> observations and ask a couple of questions.
> 
> In this section, Ken asks: "An important question is:
> Because NEAT searches by adding structure only, not by
> removing it, does the complexity always increase
> whether it helps in finding good solutions or not?"
> 
> Good question, but I'm not sure I agree that the data
> presented answers the question one way or the other.
> 
> Figure 5 shows two graphs.  The first plots the
> average number of connections among generational
> champions from 13 runs.  This is compared to the
> complexity of 5 runs in which fitness was assigned
> randomly, with the same evolutionary parameters.  But
> instead of showing the average number of connections
> among the population, the averages of the smallest and
> largest members of each generation are shown.
> 
> Why? Why not show the average complexity of the random
> population as a whole, instead of the range?  Just
> eyeballing it, it looks like such an average would
> result in a plot of complexity reasonably close to the
> plot for the average fittest individual complexity (of
> course, since we're only shown the max and min,
> there's no way of knowing whether most members of the
> random-fitness population tended toward one extreme or
> the other).
> 
> It seems as if the paper is suggesting that in the
> random-fitness population, because some members of the
> population complexified greatly, while others did not
> complexify much at all, that this demonstrates that
> complexification correlates with increased fitness. 
> But that doesn't look like a conclusion that you can
> draw, at least from what's presented here.
> 
> It would seem more appropriate to compare the min and
> max complexities of members of the regular and the
> random-fitness runs.  Is the range of complexity in a
> fitness-based run similar to the range in a
> random-fitness run?  
> 
> Or, as I've suggested above, compare the average
> complexity of the fittest member in the regular runs
> to the average complexity of the entire population of
> random-fitness runs.  As it stands, it seems like a
> comparison of apples and oranges.
> 
> Intuitively, it seems to me that the phenomenon of
> maintaining such a range of complexity in a
> random-fitness population has to do with NEAT's
> handling of speciated mating.  Less complex
> individuals are going to only mate with one another,
> while individuals that are a result of mutated
> complexity are likewise going to only mate with one
> another.  There is no selection pressure to drive
> simple species to extinction, correct?  So they'll
> hang around.  But since NEAT is incrementally adding
> features, later generations will tend to include more
> and more complex individuals, even when their fitness
> is not being evaluated.  So the average complexity of
> the population is going to tend to increase over time,
> isn't it?
> 
> The paper says: "These bounds show that the increase
> in complexity is not inevitable; both very simple and
> very complex species exist in the population
> throughout the run."
> 
> What "increase in complexity" is the paper referring
> to?  There is most definitely an increase in
> complexity in the most complex member of each
> generation, and there seems to be an increase in the
> average complexity of the population.  All this data
> shows is that some less complex members of the
> population are retained throughout a random-fitness
> run, that not every member of every species
> complexifies.  And again, I just don't see how this
> demonstrates a correlation between fitness and
> complexification.
> 
> Derek
>
